moves.1. e4: I double step my king's pawn to allow his bishop and my queen some freedom...
moves.1... e6: ...but my opponent only single steps the king's pawn...
moves.2. d4: ...so I double step my queen's pawn to give her bishop freedom, too...
moves.2... b6: ...and my opponent moves up a knight's pawn, not doubt hoping to fianchetto the bishop...
moves.3. d5: ...so I push my queen's pawn to attack the king's pawn...
moves.3... Be7: ...but my opponent declines to take it...
moves.4... dxe6: ...and lose mine, opening up the d-file...
moves.6. Nc3: I bring up my knight to cover my pawn from a potential bishop attack...
moves.6... Ne7 7. Bf4: ...and bring out my bishop to eye up the c-pawn...
moves.7... Bb7 8. Nb5: ...and my knight also eyes up the pawn...
moves.8... a6: ...but my opponent sees that I could potentially capture the rook, so moves the flank pawn...
moves.9... Bxc7 10. Bxc7: ...and trade my knight for a bishop.
moves.10... Nd7: As the knight moves out of harm's way...
moves.11... O-O 12. O-O-O: Castling queenside to pressures the d-knight...
moves.14... bxc5: ...in return for my bishop, disconnecting and isolating the queenside pawns.
moves.15. Rd7: Now I advance my rook to the 7th rank...
moves.16. Rd3: ...and my rook to retreat four ranks...
moves.16... Red8: ...but my opponent contests the open file...
moves.18. Ne2: Why did I do this move?
moves.18... f5: As my opponent pressures my e-pawn...
moves.20. Ng3: What was I thinking here, too?
moves.20... a5: Moving the flank pawn let me off the hook...
moves.21. Nxf5 exf5: ...as I get the knight-for-knight swap I was hoping for.
moves.22. Bc4+: Now my bishop can attack the king...
moves.23. Rd1: ...as my rook can control the d5 square further...
